qas.question: What types of instruments do irish player prefer?

answers.text: might be adequate for Irish traditional music, virtually all Irish players prefer flat-backed instruments with oval sound holes

qas.question: Why is it said that the Italian style can't hold their own session?
Which type mandolin had a tendency not to stay in the player's lap?
Which mandolin was preferred for formal performances and recordings?
What was the Irish style mandolin reminiscent of?
What types of instruments do Italian player prefer?
Why is it said that the Italian style can hold their own session?
Which type mandolin didn't have a tendency not to stay in the player's lap?
Which mandolin wasn't preferred for formal performances and recordings?
What was the Italian style mandolin reminiscent of?

context: Though almost any variety of acoustic mandolin <a0_0>might be adequate for Irish <b5_0>traditional music<b5_0/>, virtually all Irish players prefer flat-backed instruments with oval sound holes<a0_0/> to the Italian-style bowl-back mandolins or <a2_0>the <b7_0>carved-top mandolins with f-holes<b7_0/><a2_0/> favoured by bluegrass mandolinists. The former are often <a1_0><b6_0>too soft-toned<b6_0/><a1_0/> to hold their own in a session (as well as having a tendency to not stay in place on the player's lap), whilst the latter tend to sound harsh and overbearing to the traditional ear. The f-hole mandolin, however, does come into its own in a traditional session, where its brighter tone cuts through the sonic clutter of a pub. Greatly preferred for formal performance and recording are <a3_0><b8_0>flat-topped "Irish-style" mandolins<b8_0/><a3_0/> (reminiscent of the <a4_0><b9_0>WWI-era Martin Army-Navy<b9_0/> mandolin<a4_0/>) and carved (arch) top mandolins with oval soundholes, such as the Gibson A-style of the 1920s.
